objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to develop LitLinker, an interactive system powered by a large language model, to facilitate the ideation of interdisciplinary contexts for teaching literature in elementary schools.
objective.evidence: In this paper, we develop LitLinker via an iterative design process involving 13 teachers to facilitate the ideation of interdisciplinary contexts for teaching literature.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the challenge that neither conversational applications of LLMs nor existing LLM-powered tools can offer a comprehensive solution for ideating interdisciplinary contexts for literature teaching.
knowledge_gap.evidence: However, neither conversational applications of LLMs (e.g., ChatGPT) nor these LLM-powered tools can offer a comprehensive solution for the challenges at hand.

answer: LitLinker is an interactive system that supports the ideation of interdisciplinary contexts for literature classes.
The system uses a user-centered design approach involving 13 Chinese literature teachers.
LitLinker provides a structured workflow that aligns with teachers' habitual practices in interdisciplinary context ideation.
The system includes a Context Pool with original contexts derived from popular words and textbooks.
evidence: First, we introduce LitLinker, an interactive system that supports the ideation of interdisciplinary contexts for literature classes.
To develop LitLinker, we follow a user-centered design approach that involves in total 13 Chinese literature teachers.
LitLinker aligns its behavior with teachers’ habitual practices in interdisciplinary ideation.
The Informal Education Database contains 113 original contexts derived from a famous Chinese journal Yao Wen Jiao Zi’s 'Annual Popular Words (2008-2023)'.

inspirational_papers.evidence: Inspired by [27, 58], LitLinker aligns its behavior with teachers’ habitual practices in interdisciplinary ideation (DP1). We designed an LLM-based multi-agent system to simulate human collaboration. Following the multi-agent collaborative framework by Hong et al. [26], we decompose the task into multiple steps, allowing agents to use tools when necessary and interact with the user for feedback. The effectiveness of the content generated through this architecture relies on a comprehensive Context Pool (DP4) and carefully designed prompts (DP2, DP3), which will be introduced in Section 4.2.2 and Section 4.2.3, respectively.

steps.step: Select interdisciplinary subjects and reading materials for exploration.
steps.evidence: To initiate the exploration process, users are required to select the interdisciplinary subjects and reading materials they wish to explore.

steps.step: Generate recommended contexts based on selected materials.
steps.output: A series of context cards with detailed descriptions.
steps.evidence: Upon clicking the 'Generate Recommended Contexts' button, LitLinker displays a series of context cards.

steps.step: Analyze texts based on selected context.
steps.output: In-depth single-text analysis and pairwise comparisons.
steps.evidence: Texts that are most relevant to the selected context are displayed at the top in Texts Exploration View, with each reading material accompanied by the analysis.

steps.output: A comprehensive course plan with introduction and activities.
steps.evidence: Subsequently, users are prompted to enter the 'Expected number of lessons' and select the 'Generate Introduction and Course Plan' to create a comprehensive course plan.

tools.name: GLM-4
tools.description: Used as the LLM to power LitLinker for generating contexts and analyses.
tools.evidence: LitLinker is a web application powered by the LLM GLM-4.

tools.name: Zhipu embedding-3 model
tools.description: Used for embedding texts and contexts for retrieval.
tools.evidence: Before the application is implemented, all original contexts and reading materials are embedded using the Zhipu embedding-3 model.

performance_summary.summary: LitLinker leads to deeper integration of different subjects in the outcome lesson plan, is deemed significantly more satisfying and efficient, and significantly reduces task workload.
performance_summary.evidence: The quantitative results indicate that LitLinker leads to deeper integration of different subjects in the outcome lesson plan, is deemed significantly more satisfying and efficient, and significantly reduces task workload.

baselines.name: LLM chatbot
baselines.description: Used as a comparison to evaluate LitLinker's effectiveness.
baselines.evidence: A within-subjects study (N=16) shows that compared to an LLM chatbot, LitLinker can improve the integration depth of different subjects and reduce workload in this ideation task.

future_directions.name: Improve Context Diversity
future_directions.description: Collect more diverse and suitable contexts from various sources to enhance the system's recommendations.
future_directions.evidence: Future work could consider identifying suitable types of informal contexts with teachers and collecting more such contexts from diverse sources.

future_directions.name: Enhance User Customization
future_directions.description: Allow teachers to easily customize the system based on their needs to achieve more effective collaboration with AI.
future_directions.evidence: We look forward to building an extensible version of LitLinker in which teachers without programming skills can easily customize the system based on their needs.
